title: Before 1 October 2018, will either Russia or the United States announce that it is suspending its participation in or withdrawing from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty?
preds: timing is not sufficient for such a development

There is virtually no chance either nation would withdraw from this treaty over the next 72 hours. In the balance is the extension of the 2010 New START treaty, due to  expire in 2021. President Trump has expressed reluctance to renew the agreement in its current form. Since the July 2018 there have been two iterations of high level U.S.-Russia talks held, including one between the Heads of State. This has seemed to decrease tension. The U.S. recently certified a Russian surveillance aircraft for the Open Skies program. This is an indication of both leaders viewing a measure of credibility at stake with reaching a positive outcome.
With less than a week remaining in this question there is almost no chance that this event will occur

If there were likely to be any movement towards a formal announcement of withdrawal or even suspension in the next 5 days, would expect to see different language coming from both sides.

The INF does not expire until 2021. Recent U.S.-Russia talks seem to have reduced tension. Although a New START Treaty is being considered for extension, there should be no anticipation for the expedited sunsetting of the INF. The U.S. believes Russia violated the INF by testing and deploying a prohibited Intermediate missile system. Russia believes the U.S. has already de facto withdrawn from the INF through its deployment of the Aegis Missile System Ashore in Romania. Putin asserts the system can be easily modified to become an intermediate missile platform and that the U.S. is making provocative moves to intentionally give cause for its future exit from the INF. Still, U.S. National Security Advisor's recently held bilateral talks with his Russian counterpart specifically addressing this issue which appears to have been fruitful with reduced tension.

I believe that with the current governments of both countries, it is not unreasonable to expect sudden drastic actions. The recent negotiations with NK have begun to quietly head south, with NK making claims that previously announced agreements were made. It would not be uncharacteristic for the current head of the US government to make a sudden announcement in order to drive NK back to the agreement. Similarly with Russia, they have publicly made claims that US drones violate the agreement already. The suspension of this treaty may be used as a bargaining chip, if the current dispute over potential interference with midterm elections continues.

Under normal circumstances I believe this would be much lower, however, President Trump has proven himself capable of taking drastic moves if he feels like it may suit his (often public relations related) purposes. That being said, I doubt that Russia would take this step - their election interference in Western democracies has begun driving wedges into old alliances and sowing distrust. To withdraw from this treaty would risk galvanizing NATO countries to come to the defense of Eastern European nations. Conversely, at a time where its commitment to Western alliances has come under scrutiny, it is unlikely the Trump administration would risk this move, especially when known Russia hawks like Mike Pompeo and John Bolton hold important foreign policy positions.

There is a remote chance (5% or less) that either Russia or the United States would officially withdraw from the INF treaty before 1 October 2018. The treaty, signed by the USSR and the U.S. in 1987 with the goal of eliminating the respective short range (500-1,000 kilometers) and intermediate range (1,000 - 5,000+ km) missiles, notably did not include provisions concerning sea-launched missiles. In other words, both sides can deploy ship or submarine-launched vectors with ranges comparable to those considered in the treaty, without violating it. Furthermore, since 2016 the Russians have permanently deployed IRBMs in their Kaliningrad Oblast (located between Poland and Lithuania), justifying the move with the need to "counterbalance" American initiatives aimed at deploying anti-ballistic missile defense systems to Europe. All considered, rescinding the treaty in the short term would serve only the political purpose of increasing the tension between the two superpowers. I deem such course of action unlikely for both Russia and the U.S., considering the current political climate on both sides.

Trump currently preoccupied with domestic issues, and hurricane Florence is likely to do significant damage and further distract Trump interests. Russia unlikely to pull out due to the risk of sanctions. There is also an international taboo when it comes to nuclear capabilities.

The 1 October 2018 deadline and the stipulation for an announcement makes me think this leans towards unlikely. The 2019 National Defense Authorization Act which allows research into INF prohibited systems illustrates a willingness to step up to the line.

Russia’s precedent for “suspending” treaties with the US—set in 2007 when it suspended its implementation of the Conventional Forces in Europe—and the US’s recent answer in the 2019 National Defense Authorization Act, which includes provisions that allow the US to “suspend” its implementation of the INF Treaty in response to a violation by Russia, open the door for this type of action. However, President Trump wants to continue trying to improve relations with Russia, and suspending or withdrawing from the treaty would be antithetical to that goal. It also provides little benefit for the US when other types of weapons factor much more prominently today than Cold War-era ballistic missiles. President Putin is already taking aggressive steps in other domains (i.e., annexation of Crimea, 2016 US election meddling) that have been exposed and have resulted in further sanctions and indictments against Russians. Therefore, he also is unlikely to take such a provocative step as openly suspending or withdrawing from the treaty when Russia has relatively little to gain from such an action.

https://www.brookings.edu/testimonies/the-future-of-the-inf-treaty/
FWIW: Trump and Trump admin. currently seem preoccupied with domestic issues, midterm elections + N. Korea. Hurricane Florence/recovery may require focused admin. effort in the near-term.

Deployment of US troops and weapons to Eastern Europe encroach on Russian regional dominance. Russia violated the treaty because they secretly deployed a new cruise missile but USA will not suspend the treaty nor Russia but USA will begin development of a new GLCM with a range of 5,500 kilometers that is prohibited by the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty.  In my personal opinion I believe that this could be a chance to actualize more technology because China is advancing in this kind of missiles.

The United States has accused Russia of violating the treaty yet Russia denies these allegations. In addition, the introduction of new BMD's by the United States in Eastern Europe only further puts both countries in a security dilemma, whereas Russia would see this as justification to increase their own offensive/defensive capabilities. Taking these facts into account, it is likely that the INF Treaty will not last as it is in its current form in the coming years, but it is highly unlikely that either country will withdraw from the Treaty so quickly.

Considering the highly suspect and unusual relationship that President Trump has with the Kremlin, it is highly doubtful that either country will withdraw.  The United States is riven with considerable internal strife within the domestic realm that has distracted it from issues within the international arena. Russia, with its extensive influence campaign within the West, and its focus on Ukraine and Syria, is in a position of leverage that would be undermined by withdrawing or suspending the treaty.

I think the stakes are too high with weapons of such magnitude to make a decision like that in the global arena. The implications extend beyond borders and the US has a pre-fixed demand on weapons production to alter it at the current time.

I see no benefit in either party withdrawing from the treaty. Putin won the election no long ago and has no need for any type of political move - especially considering the judicial turmoil President Trump finds himself in. Trump is very unpredictable and he could suggest something like this to change the news from his legal troubles but I do not think senior officials or Mattis would allow it.
This will languish till someone shows an interest then it will be clear how much groundwork has been going on.

I do not think this action will occur before 1 October 2018.  It seems to be too soon, and there is not a lot of foreshadowing as such.  Nevertheless, I do think that, at some future point, one of the two countries (or maybe both) will announce a suspension of the treaty (I'm unsure of a withdraw, given its treaty status and thus greater amount of legislative hurdles).  However, both leaders do not like to be hindered by anything seen as weakening their country's defense or personal image.  Both have already taken similar steps with other treaties or agreements such as the economic sphere.  Both have demonstrated a propensity for bold (maybe even considered rash) action, even military in nature.  And both have already spoken about the dislike of the treaty; both leaders also being the type to want to actual follow through on their statements.

Looking at the current situation with New Start:
“The U.S. and Russia have stuck to the terms of New Start, which was signed eight years ago by their then presidents, Barack Obama and Dmitry Medvedev.”
“The treaty allows a five-year extension by mutual consent. Moscow has said it was open to discussion on the issue, and in an interview in March, Putin voiced interest in an extension or even possible further cuts in warhead numbers.”

With those milestones reached, the top Pentagon official for nuclear and missile policy, Rob Soofer told the Senate on 11 April, “we’re going to begin a whole of government review of the pros and cons of extending that treaty.”

Considering recent (and credible) allegations of violations on both sides, the future of the INF treaty is indeed very uncertain. However, the current level of contention over alleged treaty violation is still rather moderate, and it is extremely unlikely that by Oct. 2018 either side would take the dramatic step to suspend participation in or withdraw from the treaty. Even though the US has voiced vocal criticism of Russia's alleged treaty violations, it has also pursued a policy of inducing Russia back into compliance, and the latter has made no public threat of suspending or quitting the treaty. Especially considering the Trump administration's substantively appeasing attitude toward Russia, it is very unlikely that it would allow something as dramatic as suspending or quitting the treaty to happen.

I am updating this forecast to 20% because of the recent actions of Russia and the United States. As I previously discussed, the Russian Federation announced Russia has announced the existence two new nuclear-tipped missiles, including a previously secret nuclear-powered cruise missile. This announcement not only makes it clear that Russia does not intend abide by the INF treaty, but also acts as further evidence of aggression. Moreover, the recent assassination attempt by nerve agent in Great Britain is thought to be ordered by the Putin Administration and resulted in the expelling of 23 Russian diplomats in the UK, and 60 Russian diplomat in the US, and other allies are following suit. While this does not directly relate to the nuclear treaty, the rapidly increasing tensions is a good indication that either the United States or the Russian Federation will withdraw from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Treaty.

Strategically speaking, neither the US nor Russia has anything significant to gain by pulling out of the agreement at this point. On both sides, tactical missile systems are already deployed that fits the category of "intermediate"... the US in Romania, Poland and the Baltics, and Russia in Kaliningrad. Both missile systems can quickly be armed with nuclear payloads and delivery timeframes are under 5 mins on both sides. Both sides have carefully skated around the direct wording of the treaty carefully to create de facto capability of deterrent systems that, if the "spirit" of the treaty were taken into account, would probably violate it. Therefore, neither side has anything further to gain by actually officially withdrawing from it, except to needlessly make an already tense situation even more so.

Maintaining forecast for now as the weapons capabilities of both countries suggest the INF Treaty does not need to be suspended in order to modernise weapons - will continue to watch for potential political motivations that may lead to the withdrawal from the Treaty. 
NATO Annual Report 2017: 
“The Alliance also recognises the importance of the INF treaty to Euro-Atlantic security. The treaty has contributed to strategic stability and reduced the risk of miscalculation leading to conflict. The Alliance is committed to the preservation of the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty and strongly believes full compliance with this landmark arms control treaty is needed. In December 2017, NATO recognised the United States’ compliance with its obligations under the INF Treaty and its commitment to implementing the Treaty. The Alliance also welcomed the continued efforts by the United States to engage Russia to resolve concerns about Russia’s compliance with the Treaty.” 
(https://www.nato.int/nato_static_fl2014/assets/pdf/pdf_2018_03/20180315_SG_AnnualReport_en.pdf)

I’ve been looking at the events that led to the U.S. withdrawing from the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty (ABMT) in 2001. (I apologise if anyone has mentioned this in a previous forecast)
The Treaty was between the U.S. and USSR signed in 1972 with the purpose “to limit ABM systems and to adopt other measures in accordance with the provisions of this Treaty.” (https://www.state.gov/t/avc/trty/101888.htm#text) 
“The treaty limited only ABMs capable of defending against strategic ballistic missiles, without attempting to define strategic. Neither country intended to stop the development of counter-tactical ABMs. The topic became disputable as soon as more potent counter-tactical ABMs started to be capable of shooting down SLBMs, nevertheless both sides continued counter tactical ABM development” 
“March 23, 1983 President Reagan announced the Strategic Defense Initiative (SDI), a research program into ballistic missile defence which would be “consistent with our obligations under the ABM Treaty” - sounds similar to the recent statement made in the NPR: “the United States is commencing INF-Treaty compliant research and development by reviewing military concepts and options for conventional, ground-launched, intermediate range missile systems. 
(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-Ballistic_Missile_Treaty) 
(https://media.defense.gov/2018/Feb/02/2001872886/-1/-1/1/2018-NUCLEAR-POSTURE-REVIEW-FINAL-REPORT.PDF) 
The Soviets objected to the SDI, however “if the Soviets entered this new arms race, they would further cripple their economy…their policy at the time was to enter negotiations with the Americans.”
“In 1987, the USSR withdrew its opposition, concluding the SDI posed no threat and scientifically “would never work” 
SDI research was cut back towards the end of Raegan’s presidency, however President Clinton in 1999 signed the National Missile Defense Act which states: “It is the policy of the United States to deploy as soon as is technologically possible an effective National Missile Defense system capable of defending the territory of the United States against limited ballistic missile attack”
(https://www.congress.gov/bill/106th-congress/senate-bill/269/text)
(https://clintonwhitehouse5.archives.gov/WH/new/html/Wed_Oct_4_141122_2000.html) 
(https://www.armscontrol.org/act/2009_07-08/lookingback)
President Bush gave notification of withdrawal in December 2001 stating: “I have concluded the ABM treaty hinders our government’s ways to protect our people from future terrorists or rogue state missile attacks” 
Putin said the decision to withdraw was “an erroneous one” 
(http://www.nytimes.com/2001/12/13/international/bush-pulls-out-of-abm-treaty-putin-calls-move-a-mistake.html)
According to the Missile Defence Agency, “the U.S. withdrawal of the ABM in 2002 lessened the restrictions to develop and test these technologies.”  (https://www.mda.mil/about/mission.html)
saber rattling will continue but will pull back.

Since the end of the Cold War, the INF treaty has encouraged both the US and Russia to make progress on reducing their nuclear forces and is held in great regard by both sides. Due to its success, like any other treaty, both sides will try to maintain participation into the treaty until all other options are exhausted. Despite the recent perceived violations by Russia in its testing of the 9M729, it is still not a substantial attack for the treaty and there are still options left to bring Russia back into compliance. Among the most important of these options is the Special Verification Commission. Recently, Russia has criticized the United States  in its deployment of the Aegis Ashore launchers, by stating that the United States was in breach of the treaty as the launchers could carry prohibited missiles. The Commission could work by allowing inspectors to view both weapons and determine their capabilities, which would be a great sign of mutual respect. In addition, the US could pressure its allies into ensuring that the INF treaty remains a top priority on their agenda in their discussions with delegates of Russia. In summation, long term successful treaties are usually held until all options are exhausted, and the INF treaty should be no different as both sides have options for resolving disputes.

The challenge question for this week is: “Before 1 October 2018, will either Russia or the United States announce that it is suspending its participation in or withdrawing from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty?”  I am forecasting that there is a 10% probability that either Russia or the US will suspend its participation in or withdraw from the INF Treaty.  Since the treaty’s signing in 1987 by Reagan and Gorbachev, the treaty has been responsible for a fair portion of nuclear capability disarmament, such as banning ground-launched ballistic and cruise missiles with ranges between 300 and 3,300 miles.  As a result, 2,700 missiles and launchers have been destroyed by both countries.  Recent developments have made it more difficult for either country to remain committed to the treaty’s premise.  Russia has violated the treaty by deploying a prohibited ground-launched cruise missile.  This action violates the treaty’s prohibitions on producing, flight-testing, and possessing intermediate-range ground-launched missile.  On the other hand, Russia has claimed that the US has violated the treaty by possessing launchers for missile interceptors in Romania and Poland.  This is just another spat, although having potentially catastrophic consequences, in an increasingly East-West divide that is slowly taking shape.  One can not assume that the Trump and Putin administrations will employ any logical reason other than avoiding another Cold War that would stifle both economies.  With Trump’s bravado and Putin’s expansionist views, anything is possible at this point; therefore, I am submitting a 10% valuation on the probability of this event occurring.

I give this outcome a 1 in 5 chance of occurring. 
From its conception, the INF's value was as much (if not more) symbolic than it was strategic. It did not serve to fully eliminate the ability of either the US or Russia to strike any given target on the planet with some form of nuclear weapon. Long range ICBMs, sea-based vehicles, and strategic bombers could still allow for this capability. As such the value in the INF was largely as a symbolic agreement continuing a (somewhat disingenuous) trend toward disarmament as well as a cost saving measure for both parties. If one is faced with evaluating the likelihood of either party suspending the agreement, the first step is to assess what would be gained. In my estimation, just as the value in entering it was largely symbolic, the main possibilities for leaving it would also be based in some type of symbolism. The United States has a president and congress who may increasingly find themselves in a position where appearing to be strong in opposition to Russia on anything will be politically useful. Additionally, Russia has grown increasingly brazen in its willingness to break international agreements and understandings without any realistic expectation of rebuke. As such a US suspension of the INF could serve as a means for the US administration/congress to  appear to be anti-Russia and publicly admonish Russian aggressive behavior in context that is not likely to be particularly impactful. 
Both have implemented programs that are fundamental violations of the INF, if not in its wording in its spirit. Given that there has, to this point, been no repudiation for these violations, it is hard to see that there is any great strategic value in leaving the INF. For this reason as well as the fact that most observers (in the US particularly) don't rate the INF high on their list of important international agreements, making it weak as a symbolic token of defiance against Russia make it less likely to be used in this manner. The wild card nature of President Trump forces one to increase any assessment of what is remotely possible though which is why I made this outcome as likely as I did.

I give a 26% chance for this event because I think Russia could use unrelated events to pull out of the treaty such as U.S. arms exports to Ukraine, the new U.S. nuclear strategy, or the Mueller investigation into Russian election meddling.

The utility of the INF Treaty as it currently exists: missile technology has advanced significantly since 1987 such that the subsection of weapons it was designed to prohibit (approximately 500-1000km) can now be launched by other means not explicitly covered by the INF treaty - namely by sea. If the current canvas of missile capabilities can be launched in ways that bypass the INF treaty, one would then have to consider the principle strength of the INF Treaty to be the fact that it reflects a moment of solidarity in time rather than a functional agreement that limits certain types of missiles.
